page.title: 03 Ecology-The Ribble Marshes
page.content: The Ribble Marshes national nature reserve covers 2302 hectares of salt marsh and mudflats. About half the area is vegetated salt marsh ("greenmarsh") on which cattle graze, the remaining half being mud and sand flats. The big bank was built in 1890,and there are 20-30,000 birds visiting the estuaries, which are a protected habitat. 1.75 million pounds was paid to Mr.Herimar, the previous owner. Knots, Bar-tailed Godwits,and Dunlin are Autumn visitors,as well as some 10-20,000 Wigeons,Oystercatchers, Pintails,Redshanks,and Teals. From May to September some 900 head of cattle are grazed on the marsh, brought from as far as Leyland. The grazng animals occasionally destroy the nests of birds by treading on them.
